title: Hint 1: Recalling the Equation for Equilibrium
text: To find the temperature at which the liquid and vapor phases of water are in equilibrium, use the Gibbs free energy equation at standard conditions.

title: Hint 2: Understanding Gibbs Free Energy
text: The Gibbs free energy change (ΔG) for a process at equilibrium is zero. The equation is given by $$ΔG=ΔH-TΔS$$, where ΔH is the enthalpy change, T is the temperature, and ΔS is the entropy change.

title: Scaffold 1: Rearrange the Equation
text: Rearrange the equation $$ΔG=ΔH-TΔS$$ to solve for T.

title: Hint 3: Check Units Consistency
text: Ensure the units are consistent. Convert all quantities to the same units before substituting into the equation.

title: Scaffold 2: Convert Units
text: Convert the molar entropy from $$\frac{J}{K}$$ mol to $$\frac{kJ}{K}$$ mol.

title: Scaffold 3: Substitute Values
text: Substitute the enthalpy and entropy values into the rearranged equation $$T=\frac{\Delta H}{\Delta S}$$ to find the equilibrium temperature.

title: Scaffold 4: Calculate Temperature
text: Perform the calculation using the values from the previous step.
